item.rel_title: Air Pollution Reduction and Mortality Benefit during the COVID-19 Outbreak in China
item.rel_abs: To control the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, China undertook stringent traffic restrictions and self-quarantine measures. We herein examine the change in air pollution levels and the potentially avoided cause-specific mortality during this massive population quarantine episode. We found that, due to the quarantine, NO2 dropped by 22.8 g/m3 and 12.9 g/m3 in Wuhan and China, respectively. PM2.5 dropped by 1.4 g/m3 in Wuhan but decreased by 18.9 g/m3 across 367 cities. Our findings show that interventions to contain the COVID-19 outbreak led to air quality improvements that brought health benefits which outnumbered the confirmed deaths due to COVID-19 in China
item.rel_authors: Chen, K.; Wang, M.; Huang, C.; Kinney, P. L.; Paul, A. T.
